answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Steve,
Although I am not a local government official I have found some documents that show examples of creating a business case for eProcurement software in both the UK and Australia. I am not sure how their cases will relate to the US, but they still provide useful examples and general themes.
The document from the UK provides a detailed plan of not only how to develop this plan, but why eProcurement is important for local governments:
http://bit.ly/ePlRKa
The guide to eProcurement from the Australian government focuses on how to create a case for this software and how to make it effective. 
http://bit.ly/ewNJSH
I hope this helps,
Amanda Dodge
International City/County Management Association
Knowledge Network Intern
202-962-3699
adodge@icma.org

author: Steve Smeeth
text:
Hello,
As we all know, economic challenges have brought two subjects a lot of attention lately: procurement and cloud-based computing. it seems that local governments are recognizing procurement practices represent a significant cost-savings opportunity. And cloud-based services represent lower expenses and less IT management.
It seems like the hurdle for these procurement departments to take advantage of eProcurement is the perceived entry cost and understanding of the many layers of short and long-term savings.
I'm curious to know if anyone thinks these departments would benefit from or be inspired by guidance on making a compelling business case to power their potential desire for eProcurement software?
i appreciate your response.
title: Business Case for eProcurement
